newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- down 1/4 amid new issues.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- down 1/4 amid new issues.

text.p: U.S. municipal bonds lost 1/8 to 1/4 point Tuesday after a large slate of new issue pricings, bid-wanted lists in the secondary, and a downturn in the Treasury market.
The government long bond was off 10/32 at 98-25/32 to yield 6.72 percent in late New York trading.
In addition to several bid-wanted lists circulating, the new issue calendar was heavy, though market participants said the deals went well.

In competitive muni sales, PaineWebber Inc. won $65 million Wichita, Kan., water and sewer bonds and reoffered the 2016 maturity at 5.35 percent. To see the $27 million of remaining balances, double click on nN1715095.
Goldman Sachs & Co. won $60 million University of Maryland bonds and reoffered the 2018 maturity at 5.35 percent. To see the $17 million of remaining balances, double click on nN17215978.

In afternoon repricing action in the negotiated sector, Smith Barney Inc. said it repriced and restructed Illinois Health Facilities Authority's $188 million bond deal for Loyola University, adjusting yields in several maturities and raising the top yield in 2024 to 5.63 percent from 5.60 percent. To see the repricing, double click on nN17172726.
J.P. Morgan Securities said it raised yields in several maturities on Bexar County, Texas's $135 million health agency bonds. To see the repricing scale, double click on nN17190001.
Actively quoted secondary market issues on Tuesday included Dade County, Fla., water and sewer system FGIC 5-1/4s of 2026, which were bid up two basis points from Monday at 5.49 percent.
Jefferson County, Ala., FGIC 5-3/4s of 2027 were bid at 101-1/8, down 1/4 from Monday's level.

September municipal futures were off 3/32 to 118, while September Treasury futures fell 6/32 to 111-28/32. The MOB spread between the two contracts widened to 196 ticks from 193 at the close on Monday.

Early economic data came in about as expected, with the May Consumer Price Index up 0.1 percent overall and 0.2 percent at the core, versus estimates for gains of 0.2 pecent in each. May housing starts were down to 1.397 million units versus forecasts for 1.47 million.
Wednesday's new deals are expected to total $1.1 billion in 39 sales, according to Reuters Municipal Bond Information Group.
Negotiated offerings total $605 million in 14 sales, with a $133 million Sacramento Municipal Utility District, Calif., deal through Goldman, Sachs & Co. topping the list.
On the competitive side, 25 sales totaling $496 million are scheduled. A $200 million Massachuesetts Bay Transportation Authority deal at 1300 EDT is the largest
